reviewText: I give this DVD 5 stars by only on the condition that it is used with Original Music, without the terrible Effects.  It is somewhat ironic that this whole story by Hans Christian Andersen is about the infinite superiority of the original authentic genius (Nightingale) over the fake one (the Mechanical Nightingale), yet the default soundtrack for the DVD is set for the Original Music + Effects (which with adding atrocious clinking, clanking and applauding sounds make the default soundtrack screech as a perfect specimen of the Mechanical bird who ruins everything)!Only with deep gratitude to another reviewer (John E. Bundy) for his advice on how to get the original music, I was able to truly enjoy this wonderful opera.  Thus,  to get the original music, Stravinsky's Nightingale, and not a fake mutant created by Christian Chaudet, go to Audio option and in Dolbi 5.1 section choose Original Music.  Then...  Nightingale will sing to you as it sang to Stravinsky, Parisian audience, Diaghilev, Balanchine, Matisse and many other admirers.With this necessary adjustment done, this DVD is absolutely a masterpiece of great singing coupled with visual innovation; I think the latter is very much in the spirit of Stravinsky's art concept.  I really loved the total abandonment of the traditional mis-en-scene and mixing instead some elements of tradition, as Chinese costumes, porcelain with computer and cartoon effects - I personally think this is an excellent example of taking advantage of modern technology with discovering new heights of musical&visual; representation.This DVD is also so precious because it is so unique - there is no other film of the same opera; plus, I was so pleasantly surprised to hear that it is sung in Russian, as it should be.  This really keeps the authenticity of the piece which has elaborate history, which I state below.  For a native Russian speaker, this opera text reveals some amusing details - for example, one is when the Emperor sings: "Rassvet uzh blizitza, a soloviya vse net" -  the noon is approaching,  but the Nightingale has not arrived yet - this is such a hilarious paraphrase from "The Dame of Pique" by Tchaikovsky, where Lisa sings "Uzh polnoch blizitza, a Germana vse net"  - the midnight is approaching, but German has not arrived yet.  The singing and the text makes this opus even further much more enriching than the symphonic poem which was created later, based on this music - recently there was the Symphonic Poem "The Song of the Nightingale" was performed by Boston Symphony, but even though I was listening to Pierre Boulez and Robert Craft  recordings of the Symphonic Poem, still the music did not reveal its full magic neither with the recording, nor with listening live to the symphony orchestra.  I was very happy to find this opera on DVD, and finally everything in the music is clear.  Like "The Firebird" or "Le Sacre du printemps", this Stravinsky music shines best when performed as originally conceived - as a ballet or an opera, respectively.Also it is funny to contemplate Stravinsky's love for the birds - yet the natural Nightingale yields to the mysterious Firebird chronologically!  Still, this composer created the most amazing aviary.  Certainly his birds, and especially this Nightingale has such a marvelous compact yet beautiful form - so much more elegant than some corpulent grandiose Walkure.  Stravinsly's discipline of form truly gives the modern audience a chance to admire so much music in such a short time - in great tradition of Baroque masters, like Henri Purcell, Pergolesi, and Mozart, of course.Finally, for those who are interested, here is a history of this music which reincarnated in Musical trinity - opera, symphonic poem and ballet.While still a student of Rimsky-Korsakov, Stravinsky conceived a short opera based on Hans Christian Andersen's fairy tale The Nightingale (Le Rossignol). He composed the first act at his family's estate at Ustilug in 1908 and 1909, but then laid it aside for what he thought would be a short time because he had received an offer he couldn't refuse: Serge Diaghilev had commissioned him to write a ballet on a scenario about a mythological `firebird" for the Russian Ballet. The offer--with its guarantee of a performance in Paris by the most famous Russian performing organization of the time--was of course irresistible. Little did Stravinsky guess that the overwhelming success of The Firebird would lead to pressing commissions for more ballets and the even greater successes (and notoriety) of Petrushka and The Rite of Spring by 1913.Only after completing the latter ballet was he able to turn his mind again to his little opera. But by this time he was a completely different composer. The musical sketches for Act I had been seen and approved by Rimsky-Korsakov shortly before his death; Rimsky would scarcely have approved so audacious a score as Stravinsky was turning out five years later. After failing to interest anyone in performing the single completed act as a "lyric scene," Stravinsky decided to go ahead and complete the score, despite the inevitable disjunction of musical styles. It was possible, he felt, that the stylistic change might work dramatically, since an important change in the plot at precisely the point where he broke off in 1909 could justify the new musical language.The plot of the opera is quite simple. Indeed, the three "acts" are so brief that it really makes more sense to regard them as scenes in a one-act opera lasting about three- quarters of an hour. In the opening scene, a Chinese fisherman sings of his joy at hearing the voice of a nightingale, whose exquisite song fills the air with music. The bird's song is interrupted by a group of courtiers--absurd characters all--who have come to invite the nightingale to sing for the Emperor. Though the bird prefers the open air, it agrees to go. The second and third acts take place in the Emperor's palace (hence the justification for a change of musical style). At first the Emperor is moved to tears by the bird's song, but when three Japanese envoys arrive with a gift in the form of a dazzlingly ornate mechanical nightingale--a visual delight, though it cannot sing nearly so well--the true nightingale slips out of the room. The Emperor in a fit of pique banishes the bird from his kingdom. In the third act, the Emperor is lying ill in bed, while Death wears his royal regalia. But the nightingale returns and, by its singing, redeems the life of the Emperor, forcing Death to depart.Ultimately the opera "Le Rossignol" was produced on the stage by the Russian Ballet--on May 26, 1914, at the Paris Opera House with Pierre Monteux conducting--since the Moscow Free Theater, which had commissioned the score, had folded.But Diaghilev always preferred ballet to opera, and he approached Stravinsky in 1917 with the proposal that The Nightingale be remounted as a ballet. Stravinsky offered instead to produce a symphonic poem based on the stylistically consistent second and third acts of the opera, from which Diaghilev could make his ballet. The scenario was adapted from the original story and the symphonic poem composed in short order (mostly by adapting existing music).The first performance of the symphonic poem "Le Chant du rossignol"("The Song of the Nightingale")took place on December 6, 1919, in Geneva, with Ernest Ansermet conducting the Orchestre de la Suisse Romande.The first performance of "The Song of the Nightingale"as a ballet was delayed until 1920 and finally given on February 2, 1920, at which time the choreography was created by Leonid Massine and the stage designs by Henri Matisse, with Ernest Ansermet again conducting.Five years later, new choreography for the Russian Ballet was provided by George Balanchine.Such is the rich story of this music!  This opera&DVD; are highly recommended.

reviewText: I tuned into this midway through late one night on PBS and had to find out what it was. The mix of live action and CG is totally captivating, no small achievement in this age of big-budget special effects. I especially appreciate how the imagery, which cleverly integrates a campy Orientalism with the paraphernalia of the digital age, has a brash, disturbing edge to it that matches Stravinsky's music. This isn't your grandma's Hans Christian Andersen, and I don't think Stravinsky wanted it to be. Christian Chaudet deserves a lot of credit for finding a way to re-enchant these classics while staying true to their spirit. Well worth watching.

reviewText: This production is very tenderly and beautifully executed. For this is deserves five stars. In fairness, I must balance the glowing reviews with a note of caution for anyone who delights in music all the way from Monteverdi through Verdi. This is an abrupt departure from music in a specific key. Twelve tone music has been described , by Leonard Bernstein, for one, as music that does not seem to have a begining, middle and end..a "coming home" to the principle chord of the key. It is disorienting to a significant number of music lovers-much the way those who admire and adore the great masters of the 19th century that you find in the L'Ouvre, or the Prado of Spain...and who instead, find themselves abruptly placed in the Museum of Moder Art , or MoMA...and find yourself trying to understand the inscrutable spatters and wipes of dull pigments on large canvases. Inscrutability, madness, disturbing...these have been presented to a hapless, ignorant public that for the most part does not have any interest in modern art at all...indeed, most of them cannot name a living painter who fetches millions for a single painting! They can name sports figures and movie stars who fetch millions, however. The public just does not care at all for modern art. Indeed, the term 'modern' has taken on the oxymoronic term "Old Fashion Modernism". These works by Stravinsky were 'revolutionary' in their time, and a sensation. But today's listening audience would find it a 'period piece' at best, and difficult to listen to. The melody meanders all over , and so does the tempi. Does it still convey joy, tenderness, drama, sombreness, fright, etc...well yes it does. But so do random splashes and wipes of pigment smeared across huge canvases-which does nto really seem to have any connection to the word "skill".It remains that we still do not have any composers today who can create anything remotely grand and majestic. Proof of that is the recent sorry excuse for a musical called "Mama Mia". There is such a vast wasteland of good music emerging from this 'fin de siecle society' of ours that people hunger for it..so hungry that they think Mama Mia is just"stupendous "...? ( well...I'd keep the "stup.." part of that word )  Well it might have been grand had the producers actually hired an accomplished librettist over the mental age of 12, an actual composer, and not merely appropriated bubble gum rock from 30 years ago-which was nto considered cool then, and still is not cool... and hired performers/actors who have actually spent some time training their singing voices!  Mama Mia is, threfore, not much more than Karaoke night at the local jukejoint. Ahh...but I digress.The point is, if you love beautiful melody...you may find yourself watching this with furrowed brow, squinted eye, and mouth slightly agape....similar to your reaction to Mama Mia.
summary: Not for Lovers of the Romantic Era

reviewText: I'm astonished that anyone could not take delight in this 'collaboration' of musical and visual artistry. The one- and two-star reviews of "Le Rossignol" seem perverse and fractious to me. Obviously, this 2005 film by Christian Chaudel isn't a faithful staged performance of Igor Stravinsky's 1914 chamber opera. It's a "trope" -- a new piece of artistry built upon an older one, like the Variations that Beethoven constructed on a theme by Diabelli, or the six-part mass Monteverdi composed around the five-part mass by Gombert. Stravinsky's music remains intact, and it's never sounded more lovely, but the dramatic themes of the opera Le Rossignol have been superseded by pure visual fantasy, by exuberant pictorial artistry that parallels and embellishes the music without attempting to subsume or supplant it.Artist Christian Chaudet has done in this video fairy tale exactly what a brilliant child does when a teacher or parent tells her/him to paint impressions while listening to music. The profuse visual fantasy is entirely Chaudet's, while the music remains purely Stravinsky's. This is a display of computer graphics more dazzling than "Yellow Submarine" in its time, or the more recent "Polar Express", comparisons that seem relevant because of the pervasive  'psychedelic' stream-of-images non-narrative abstraction of all three. And the images are gorgeous, witty, hypnotic, worth enjoying in pure wonderment at the technology.And there's the wonderment of the 'sound track'! Listeners who know only Stravinsky's 'Sacre du Printemps' or 'Fire Bird' will be thrilled to hear that Stravinky could also compose delicate lyrical music. There's raucous wit to be heard in the scenes of the Emperor's court, but the fairy-tale beauty of the Nightingale's warblings and the Fisherman's rapturous celebration of that beauty are what we listeners must remember from the performance. Vsevolod Grivnov sings the Russian poetry of his role as the Fisherman superbly, and what sort of wax-stuffed ears could fail to hear the melodic grace of his first aria in his sampan? The Nightingale, that small drab brown bird whose coloratura is more beautiful than a dream, is sung by Natalie Dessay, in a short drab burlap frock amid all the panoply of lush colors and forms, whose coloratura is more beautiful than the splendor of the Emperor's court. The extraordinary French basso Laurent Naouri sings the contrasting role of the supercilious Chamberlain with properly snarly affect. The CD of their performance, by the way, dated from several years before the film. If you have the sort of sensory apparatus -- eyes and ears -- that can't absorb two streams of pleasure at once, you could always play the DVD and listen from another room - voilá le CD - and then watch the video with the sound turned off. Both experiences would be extraordinary.

reviewText: Get this DVD and also the Julie Taymore "Oedipus Rex" and you have two opposite poles of the mind and music of Stravinsky as well as the power of filmed stage opera and opera just for film. The brutal, gritty live production on stage of "Oedipus" is how that should be done. The dreamy, FX, studio production of "Le Rossignol" is just how that should be done. The music in both cases is perfection. They are perfect foils.Stravinsky - Oedipus RexThe music of "Le Rossignol" is excruciatingly beautiful. The stylistic clash resulting from Stravinsky having put the opera down to go through the epiphany of "Firebird" to "Petruchka" and finally opening...no, blowing the door off and ushering in 20th century music with "Le Sacre du Printemps" is no hindrance, as is often said. It is used by the composer to set up the contrasts of the story. These contrasts of natural with the artificial are not ignored or forgotten by director Chaudet's flashy CGI as some have stated. After all the nightingale is the only real bird in the film....Natalie Dessay is also organic and real representing the bird and it's song. It should also not go unnoticed that the "earthy" characters, the cook and the fisherman, are also the only "real" beings. Practically everyone else is incased in something normally inanimate and man made. Cigarette smoking Death is real and organic (as it is outside of film, in our own world) too. Even the emperor must break out of his beautiful but man made prison to become real... literally morphing out of a boy's dream into reality.This is a great interpretation. It will please those who know nothing of Stravinsky or opera as well as those who do. See it!

reviewText: Stravinsky's Le Rossignol [the Nightingale]is a remarkably beautiful piece.  Natalie Dessay, James Conlon, and all the musical forces engaged in the work perform with remarkable warmth and charm.  And, one must admit, Christian Chaudet's computerized animation is truly spectacular.  Why then, is this DVD such a failure as an operatic film?A written opera merges two forms of artistic creativity:  that of the dramaticist -- the libretto with the music of the composer.  Le Rossignol is based on a story by Hans Christian Andersen:  The nightingale is a bird of unassuming appearance but with the most beautiful voice.  Its song enchants a lowly Chinese fisherman, and then word of it reaches the Emperor and his court.  All are captivated by its song until the Emperor of Japan sends a spectacular, artificial nightingale as a present to the Emperor of China.  Then the Court forgets the natural bird until the Chinese Emperor lies dying.  There is a moral here:  The beauty of nature, often forgotten, is ultimately more lovely and enduring than those of artifice.  Chaudet has forgotten this moral.In Chaudet's film, when the nightingale sings in the forest, spectacular Chinese parisols spring up and twirl, but the "forest" is all but without plants.  While Stravinsky contrasts the tender lyricism of the nightingale with striking artifice of Japan's, Chaudet is all artifice and special effects.  The Disney in him corrupts and defeats the delicate beauty of this tale.
